metadata.title: A Computational Approach to Design Potential siRNA Molecules as a Prospective Tool for Silencing Nucleocapsid Phosphoprotein and 2 Surface Glycoprotein Gene of SARS-CoV-2 3 4

body_text.text: technology was harnessed to develop siRNA molecules against specific target genes namely, 24

nucleocapsid phosphoprotein gene and surface glycoprotein gene. Conserved sequence from 139 25 SARS-CoV-2 strains from around the globe was collected to construct 78 siRNA that can inactivate 26 nucleocapsid phosphoprotein and surface glycoprotein genes. Finally, through a rigorous filtering 27 process 8 siRNA molecules were selected with exerts the best action. These predicted siRNAs 28
should effectively silence the genes of SARS-CoV-2 during siRNA mediated treatment assisting in 29 the response against SARS-CoV-2 30 31

Keywords: SARS-CoV-2. Nucleocapsid phosphoprotein, Surface glycoprotein, siRNA, siDirect. virus ranges between 2-14 days (Linton et al., 2020) and in some cases, transmission is also 47 reported during asymptomatic period (Yu et al., 2020) . Some recent studies suggest that bats are 48 likely reservoir hosts for SARS-Cov-2 but the identity of the intermediate host that might have 49 facilitated transfer to human still remain elusive with some studies indicating pangoline. SARS-50
CoV-2 is assumed to spread mainly from person-to-person through respiratory droplets produced 51
when an infected person sneezes and coughs or between people who are in close contact (Chan et  52 al., 2020). 53
Coronaviruses are genetically classified into four main genera: Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, 54

Gammacoronavirus, and Deltacoronavirus (Li, 2016 contains two functional subunits: S1 & S2 subunits. The S1 subunit includes the receptor-binding 71 domain(s) and contributes to stabilization of the membrane-anchored S2 subunit that contains the 72 fusion machinery (Walls et al., 2016) . As the coronavirus S glycoprotein is surface-exposed and 73
mediates entry into host cells and N nucleocapsid protein are essential for genome replication, these 74 could be the main targets for designing therapeutics (Park et al., 2016) .
Silencing of mRNA or post-transcriptional gene silencing by RNA interference (RNAi) is a 76 regulatory cellular mechanism. RNAi is a prospective tool for the control of human viral 77

infections (Levanova and Poranen, 2018 Nanoparticles loaded with siRNA are taken up through endocytosis by the cells. These particles are 88 then trapped into the endosomes. siRNA escape endosomes and release siRNA into the cytoplasm 89 due to pH responsive mechanism or proton sponge effect. Once generated, siRNA is loaded into 90 RNA-indiced silencing complex comprising of RNA-binding protein TRBP and Argonaute 91 (AGO2). AGO2 selects the siRNA guide strand, then cleaves and ejects the passenger strand. After 92 that, the guide strand pairs with its complementary target mRNA and AGO2 slices the target. After 93 slicing, the cleaved target mRNA is released and RISC is recycled for another few rounds of slicing 94

using the same guide strand (Figure adapted CoV-2 from around the world. Conserved portions that are shorter than 21 nucleotides were omitted 248 from further analysis. Conserved sequences were put to siDirect web server to identify possible 249 targets and to generate corresponding siRNAs. siDirect performs the task in three distinct steps, 250

highly functional siRNA selection, seed-dependent off-target effects reduction, near-perfect 251 matched genes elimination. siRNA targets were found in 18 conserved regions, 5 nucleocapsid 252 phosphoprotein (Supplementary Table 4 ) and 13 surface glycoprotein (Supplementary Table 5 ). 253 U,R,A (Ui-Tei, Amarzguioui and Reynolds) rules (Table 1) The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.036335 doi: bioRxiv preprint The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.036335 doi: bioRxiv preprint siRNAs functionality is influenced by the GC-content and there is an inverse relationship of the 275 GC-content with the function of siRNA. Usually a low GC content (between 31.6 and 57.9%) is 276

ideal for a siRNA to be effective (Chan et al., 2009) . So, siRNA species that have GC content lower 277 than 31.6 were not kept in the final selection. In the study, GC content ranged from 10% to 43% for 278 all the predicted species. GC content of all the eight selected siRNAs are greater than or equal to 279 33% (Table 2) . Formation of secondary structure of siRNA may inhibit the RISC mediated 280 cleavage of target. So, the prediction of secondary structure and determination of free energy of 281
folding is crucial. So, guide strands of siRNA were subjected to RNA structure web server in order 282
to predict possible folding structure and corresponding minimum free energy. At 37•C, finally 283
selected siRNAs have free energy of folding greater than zero, which suggests the predicted 284 siRNAs are more accessible for efficient binding. DuplexFold was used to determine the target and 285
guide siRNA interaction and their corresponding binding energy. Lower binding energy indicate 286

better interaction therefore better chance of target inhibition. The values of free energy of binding of 287 all the predicted siRNAs spanned from -36.6 to -21.6 (Supplementary siRNAPred was used to determine the inhibition efficacy of the predicted siRNAs. siRNAPred uses 296
Main21 dataset which consist of 2182 siRNAs (21mer) derived from a homogeneous experimental 297
condition to predict the actual efficacy of 21mer siRNAs with high accuracy using the support 298
vector machine based method. So, siRNA candidates that have validity score greater than 1 were 299 chosen for the final selection. 300 301
In this study, eight prospective siRNA molecules were proposed to be efficient at binding and 302

cleaving specific mRNA targets of SARS-CoV-2 ( Table 2) . As the study contain a large array of 303 139 sequences of SARS-CoV-2 from around the world, the predicted therapeutic agent can be 304 employed to large scale treatment of COVID-19 pandemic.
Conclusion: 307 308

Computational methods can be employed to design and predict siRNA interaction against specific 309 gene target thereby silencing its expression. In this study, eight siRNA molecules were predicted to 310 be effective against nucleocapsid phosphoprotein and surface glycoprotein gene of 139 strains of 311 SARS-CoV-2 virus using computational method considering all maximum parameters in prime 312

conditions. In order to decelerate the COVID-19 pandemic and recover the affected individuals the 313 development of siRNA therapeutic approaches could be a promising alternative to traditional 314 vaccine designing.
Limitations: This study employed extensive computational approaches to assess the quality of the 317 designed siRNA sequences and need to be explored further in vitro lab settings.

After 484 slicing, the cleaved target mRNA is released and RISC is recycled for another few rounds of slicing 485 using the same guide strand (Jinek and Doudna, 2009 ). 486 487 Figure 2 : Secondary structures of best eight predicted siRNA with possible folding and minimum 488 free energy for consensus sequence. 489 490 Figure 3 : Predicted lowest free energy structure for binding siRNA (guide strand) and target RNA. 491 492 Figure S1 : Radial phylogenetic tree of A. nucleocapsid phosphoprotein and B. surface glycoprotein 500
using 139 strains of SARS-CoV-2 from around the world. The bootstrap value for tree construction 501 was set to 500 and Tamura-Nei model of evolution was used for both trees. 502 503

FIGREF0.text: pandemic with a magnitude which is daunting to all public health institutions in the absence of 18 specific antiviral treatment. Surface glycoprotein and nucleocapsid phosphoprotein are two 19 important proteins of this virus facilitating its entry into host cell and genome replication. Small 20 interfering RNA (siRNA) is a prospective tool of the RNA interference (RNAi) pathway for the 21 control of human viral infections by suppressing viral gene expression through hybridization and 22 neutralization of target complementary mRNA. So, in this study, the power of RNA interference 23

FIGREF1.text: COVID-19, A pandemic affecting lives of billions of people worldwide, has confronted humanity in 36 the commencement of 2020, is caused by a viral pathogen, severe acute respiratory syndrome 37 coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) or 2019-nCoV. Initial symptoms of this disease mainly include fever, 38 cough, fatigue, dyspnea & headache(Chen et al., 2020; Huang et al., 2020) or it may be 39 asymptomatic(Song et al., 2020). The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 binds directly with the 40 surface cell angiotensin converting enzyme II (ACE2) receptor present on alveolar epithelial cells 41 of lung facilitating virus entry, replication and triggers cytokine cascade mechanism(Zhou et al., 42 2020). In severe cases, patient may die due to massive alveolar damage and progressive respiratory 43 failure(Chan et al., 2020; Huang et al., 2020). The current detection process of SARS-CoV-2 44 carried out by most countries is using real-time RT-PCR, although several other methods are also 45 being developed(Chu et al., 2020; Corman et al., 2020; Khan et al., 2020). Incubation period for the 46

FIGREF4.text: Predicted lowest free energy structure for binding siRNA (guide strand) and target 262 RNA. The structures are for A. n7 B.g15 C. g21 D. g22 E. g44 F. g46 G. g59 H. g70 siRNAs 263 and their corresponding targets. 264 265 Tm = (1000*ΔH) / (A +ΔS+R ln (CT/4)) -273.15 +16.6log [Na + ] 266 Here, 267 ▪ ΔH (kcal/ mol) represents the sum of the nearest neighbor enthalpy change 268 ▪ A is the helix initiation constant (-10.8) 269 ▪ ΔS represents the sum of the nearest neighbor entropy change 270 ▪ R is the gas constant (1.987 cal/deg/mol) 271 ▪ CT represents the total molecular concentration of the strand (100 µM) and 272 ▪ Concentration of Sodium, [Na + ] was fixed at 100 mM 273 274

TABREF2.text: Rules of Ui-Tei (Ui-Tei et al., 2004), Amarzguioui (Amarzguioui and Prydz, 2004) and Reynolds 133 (Reynolds et al., 2004) were used(Table 1) and the melting temperature was kept below 21.5 °C as 134 a default parameter for siRNA duplex. 135 136 137Table 1. Rules/Algorithm to construct siRNAs.Rule NameDescriptionUi-TeiA/U at the 5' terminus of the sense strand G/C at the 5' terminus of the antisense strand At least 4 A/U residues in the 5' terminal 7 bp of sense strand No GC stretch longer than 9nt Occurrence of three or moreA/U base pair at position 15-19 of sense strand (Each A/U base pair in this region earns one point) Low internal stability at target site (Tm > −20•C) (one point) Presence of U at position 10 of the sense strand (one point) Presence of A at position 3 of the sense strand (one point) Presence of A at position 19 of the sense strand (one point) Absence of G at position 13 of the sense strand (one point) Threshold for efficient siRNAs score >= 6 138 Off target similarity search 139 140 Blast search was performed against human genome and transcriptome using the standalone blast 141 package (Camacho et al., 2009) to identify the possible off target matches. The e-value was set to 142 1e-10 to reduce the stringency of the search condition thereby increasing the chances of random 143 matches. 144 145 GC content calculation & Secondary Structure Prediction 146 147 OligoCalc (Kibbe, 2007) was used to calculate the GC content. The secondary structure of siRNAs 148 were predicted along with the respective free energy using MaxExpect (Lu, Gloor and Mathews, 149 2009) program in the RNA structure web server (Bellaousov et al., 2013). The higher values 150 indicate better candidates as those molecules are less prone to folding. 151 152 Calculation of RNA-RNA interaction through thermodynamics 153 154Higher interaction between the target and the guide strand serves a better predictor for siRNA 155 efficacy. Therefore, the thermodynamic interaction between the target strand and the siRNA guide156 strand was predicted with the aid of DuplexFold (Piekna-Przybylska et al., 2010) program of the Tm) values for all the predicted siRNAs were less than 21.5 °C which 192suggests the ability of predicted siRNAs to avoid non-target binding.193 194Off-target Binding Exclusion Using Blast 195 196Standalone blast search against human genome and transcriptome did not reveal any off-target 197match. This shows that our predicted siRNA would not interact in any other places other than the
